executive_summary: Building exterior cleaners have performed well in recent years, but revenue growth has been volatile. As wage growth soared in the late 2010s, household income increased. Since individuals had more money, they spent more on home improvements, raising demand for building exterior cleaners. COVID-19 caused corporate profit to plunge, resulting in reduced nonresidential construction and falling revenue. Consumer spending soared as the economy recovered from the pandemic, boosting demand for building exterior cleaning services from the residential and nonresidential sectors.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Incomes Increased Private Spending on Home Improvements
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The US economy was very strong in the late 2010s because the United States was at the end of an expansion that began immediately following the 2008 financial crisis. High GDP growth contributed to rising wages and record-low unemployment. Higher wages pushed up per capita disposable income and increased the percentage of households making more than $100,000 per year, so individuals had more funds to improve their homes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 CAUSED NONRESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION TO PLUNGE
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As COVID-19 ravaged the country, state and local governments shut down businesses, causing a significant drop in consumer spending. Since households weren't going to stores anymore, corporate profit plunged. Low corporate profit forced businesses to spend less on the construction and improvement of the buildings they owned (e.g., offices, department stores), reducing downstream demand for building exterior cleaners.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE PANDEMIC RECOVERY RESULTED IN SOARING CONSUMER DEMAND
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the population became vaccinated, state and local governments reopened businesses, eased mask-wearing requirements and eased social distancing measures. The government gave out wads of cash during the pandemic, so when Americans could go out again, consumer demand skyrocketed.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Interest Rates Have Caused Revenue Growth to Slow
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Expansive monetary policy, excessive government spending and supply chain disruptions caused inflation to reach record-highs in 2022. To combat high inflation, the Federal Reserve has been increasing interest rates. Higher rates make it more expensive to purchase homes. Since fewer residences are being purchased, demand for building exterior services has slowed.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Solid Economic Conditions Will Spur Demand For Building Exterior Cleaners
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite current challenges related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, the economy will recover during the outlook period. Steadily rising GDP will boost corporate profit, giving businesses the funds to invest in nonresidential structures and internal improvements. Since these businesses have more places to look after, they'll pay building exterior cleaning companies to ensure their establishments look presentable to their customers, increasing revenue for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand From The Residential Sector Will Stabilize
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Spending on building exterior cleaning services from households fell during the end of the current period, as high rates discouraged homebuying and improvement. While interest rates aren't anticipated to decline by that much, consumers will adapt to the higher cost of borrowing during the outlook period, causing homebuying to recover. Since more individuals will purchase property, demand for building exterior cleaners from households will expand, contributing to solid revenue growth during the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Industry Will Expand As It Gains Entrants
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Becoming a building exterior cleaner will become more popular as demand from the nonresidential and residential sectors will be solid, causing more individuals will enter the industry. The industry will remain service-based, so barriers to entry will stay low, causing the number of establishments and enterprises to increase. Entry into the industry will also be spurred by increased technological progress.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling Oil Prices Will Dampen Revenue Growth Somewhat
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Building exterior cleaning companies often benefit from high energy prices, as they can pass them on to their buyers, which increases their revenue. Oil and gas prices that are too high often constrain revenue for the industry since businesses and households simply choose to clean their structures themselves when prices are too high. As supply chain disruptions and shocks from the conflict in Ukraine subside, oil prices will fall, reducing these surcharges and eliminating a significant revenue stream for the industry.

industry_definition: Building exterior cleaners in the United States provide exterior cleaning services for residential and commercial buildings. Services include power washing, window cleaning, and various other exterior maintenance tasks.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady Barriers To Entry Level

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Number of businesses
threats: Low Outlier Growth - Value of private nonresidential construction

key_trends: The industry has performed well overall during the current period.
The pandemic recovery resulted in soaring consumer demand that benefited growth, but high-interest rates have recently threatened spending from the residential sector.

Building exterior cleaners will display growth during the outlook period, but they will face some challenges. Rising incomes will increase the number of businesses, boosting demand from the nonresidential sector. Declining oil prices will reduce revenue from surcharges, dampening revenue growth somewhat.
Building exterior cleaners are subject to a slew of different regulations. These include occupational safety rules, environmental regulations and pandemic-era rules.

Building exterior cleaners are represented by many private organizations. These include the United Association of Mobile Contract Cleaners (UAMCC) and the Building Service Contractors Association International (BSCAI).

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households and individual consumers who require exterior cleaning services for their residences.
Commercial, office, retail and multifamily apartment markets that require exterior cleaning services.
Government buyers requiring exterior cleaning for public schools, agency buildings, prisons and other institutions.
Other clients such as non-profit organizations requiring exterior cleaning services.

products_and_services.product_description: Cleaning and maintenance of swimming pools.
Sweeping and cleaning of parking lots.
Cleaning of ventilation systems and ducts.

tier_1_suppliers: Soap & Cleaning Compound Manufacturing in the US
Pump & Compressor Manufacturing in the US
SUV & Light Truck Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Construction & Mining Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Commercial Real Estate in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Growth in the number of businesses represents a potential opportunity for building exterior cleaners in the United States as more businesses expand the industry's potential target market, leading to higher demand for services.
As the number of households rise, the supply of customers who want the outside of their homes to be cleaned will increase, aiding the industry.

Rising per capita disposable income positively correlates with higher demand for exterior building cleaning services as households are less likely to turn away from professional services and undertake do-it-yourself cleaning projects.

When corporate profit rises, companies have more money to spend on the industry's services, boosting revenue. Higher profit also gives businesses funds to purchase new buildings, providing growth opportunities.
As the number of new nonresidential buildings increases, companies have more locations to clean, boosting demand for building exterior cleaning services.
As the price of oil increases, service prices and revenue rise but profits decrease. Very high energy prices may cause some customers to clean exteriors themselves, hindering industry performance.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region contains the largest share of business establishments compared to its population distribution.
The Southwest region has a higher percentage of establishments compared to its population share.
The West region has a higher percentage of establishments compared to its population share.
The Great Lakes region has a lower percentage of establishments relative to its population distribution.
The Mid-Atlantic region has a lower percentage of establishments relative to its population distribution.
The New England region has a lower percentage of establishments relative to its population distribution.

regulations_points.regulation_description: While licensing requirements vary by state, many localities require building exterior cleaners to have certifications to do business. Many states specifically force pool cleaning technicians to be certified. This affects the industry, as pool cleaning is a major service that building exterior cleaners offer. Sellers of products that don't need specific certifications still often need business licenses to operate in their state.

OSHA ensures that employees of building exterior cleaners work in safe and fair working conditions. Specifically, the agency regulates workers' chemical exposure since many cleaners use dangerous substances. OSHA also ensures that workers are paid fairly, receive just compensation when injured and wear protective equipment when put in dangerous situations.

The EPA regulates building exterior cleaners through the Clean Water Act (CWA). The agency ensures that companies can only release chemicals into the water up to a specific limit, as an excessive release of these substances would be dangerous to the surrounding environment. Building exterior cleaners are also regulated by the Clean Air Act (CAA), as some machines (e.g., lawnmowers, snowblowers) can release toxic chemicals into the air.

Building exterior cleaners were forced to engage in social distancing and enforce mask-wearing laws during COVID-19. The Federal Government also made paid family and medical leave laws more comprehensive, which increased operational complexities in the industry.

factors_decreased_barrier.factor: Globalization level is low to steady.

basis_points.basis_title: Price, quality of services and location
basis_points.basis_description: Building exterior cleaners compete with each other on price, quality of services and location.
The industry faces external competition from do-it-yourself (DIY) homeowners, landscaping companies and building management associations.

Most small companies and nonemployers operate within their own town or city. Localization makes it more difficult for large players to gobble up the industry, decreasing concentration and boosting internal competition.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Building exterior cleaners don't manufacture the machines they use to perform their services, so they don't need to buy plants and factories, keeping start-up costs relatively low. Since initial costs are low, many individuals start their own companies, leading to a high prevalence of nonemployers. Since the industry contains so many establishments, it's difficult for large players to take over, keeping market share concentration low.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Localization enables small players to stay alive
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most small building exterior cleaning companies operate solely in their town or city, as nonemployers and small players don't have the funds to operate nationwide.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit rose during the pandemic recovery
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: When COVID-19 hit, the economy stopped operating, causing corporate profit to plunge. Lower corporate profit reduced nonresidential construction, constraining the need for building exterior cleaners. As revenue plunged, profit declined significantly in 2020.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Rigidity Causes Compensation to Fall
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages comprise nearly a third of revenue as workers are essential in plowing snow, cleaning windows, removing material from gutters, sweeping chimneys and parking lots and providing other services. Companies often increase their employees' wages at a steady rate so workers won't get discouraged if their compensation is cut during bad economic times. Since compensation rises at a modest and steady rate, they've increased slower than other costs amid high inflation, so wages' revenue share has crept downward during the current period.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Cleaners' Ability to Pass On High Prices Keeps Purchase Costs From Rising Precipitously
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include trucks, cleaning equipment and energy. Inflation reached record-highs in 2022 because of expansive monetary policy, excessive government spending and supply chain disruptions following COVID-19. Towering inflation raised the price of trucks, cleaning equipment, energy and other materials, causing purchases' revenue share to expand during the current period.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Potential entrants don't purchase plants or assembly equipment, so capital intensity is low. The equipment they buy is reasonably durable, so depreciation costs are also very modest. Employees must engage in the strenuous work of cleaning the exteriors of buildings, so wages comprise a significant share of revenue. For these reasons, labor presents a much higher barrier to entry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Shifting incomes have created major fluctuations in revenue
volatility_points.volatility_description: Higher incomes enable households to spend more on building exterior cleaners, so the industry benefits when people have more money. Per capita disposable income surged during COVID-19 as the government gave individuals and households massive subsidies to protect them from the economic downturn. Incomes continued to soar during the pandemic recovery as more people were going back to work. Incomes have fallen recently as COVID-19 relief funds have expired. Fluctuating per capita disposable income has enhanced revenue volatility during the current period.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuating interest rates foster more uncertainty
volatility_points.volatility_description: Interest rates determine the cost of borrowing for purchasing a home, as homebuying increases when rates are low and declines when they're high. Since building exterior cleaners operate on many residential structures, shifts in homebuying affect revenue. Rates have fluctuated dramatically in recent years as the Federal Reserve has been responding to various economic crises and conditions, creating more volatility for the industry during the current period.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The Residential Market Affects Some Relevant Product Segments
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Building exterior cleaners spend lots of time improving homes. Companies provide chimney sweeping services so ash can escape homes effectively. They also clean ducts and ventilation systems so households can breathe cleaner air. More home construction will boost spending on these services, as new homeowners will pay building exterior cleaners to sanitize their chimneys, ducts and ventilation systems.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: High-Interest Rates Have Constrained Swimming Pool Construction
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Swimming pool cleaning and maintenance services make up the largest share of revenue for building exterior cleaners, comprising nearly half of revenue. These services include cleaning pools, regular maintenance and winterization. Swimming pool cleaning and maintenance is more common in warmer states, as swimming is a year-round activity. Interest rates have soared as the Federal Reserve raises the cost of borrowing to fight inflation. Higher rates make it more expensive for homeowners to borrow money to build or purchase a swimming pool, reducing swimming pool cleaning services' revenue share during the current period.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Spending on Snow Removal Services Has Displayed Volatility
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Households and businesses often pay building exterior cleaners to remove their snow. As COVID-19 constrained incomes, corporations and households were more likely to plow snow themselves, reducing demand for snow removal services. This trend reversed itself during the pandemic recovery. On top of this, Snowfall has also been very volatile.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Record-low interest rates during the pandemic encouraged more homebuying
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Record-low interest rates during the pandemic encouraged more homebuying, but soaring inflation has caused the Federal Reserve to increase the cost of borrowing, reducing residential construction and constraining demand for chimney sweeping and drain and gutter cleaning services. Overall, these segments' revenue share has fallen during the current period.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Larger operators such as ABM Industries are increasingly offering bundled service offerings to provide clients with a full-service experience; this is particularly relevant in the commercial market.

FAQs.question: Has competition from low-wage countries hurt your business?
FAQs.answer: Exterior building cleaning services are rendered at the local level, so there's no international competition relevant to operators.

FAQs.question: Does your business need to be located near key consumer or client markets?
FAQs.answer: Building exterior cleaning companies commonly use gasoline and diesel fuel to travel to customer sites. Moving away from clients raises the transportation costs for landscapers.

FAQs.question: Has your company looked into relocating its operations to lower-wage countries?
FAQs.answer: Exterior building cleaning services are performed at specific locations and cannot be outsourced outside of the country.

FAQs.question: Does your business use web-based systems for customer bookings or orders?
FAQs.answer: There's little need for web-based systems to clean the exteriors of buildings, but some operators use such technology for bookings.

FAQs.question: What technologies has your company implemented?
FAQs.answer: The industry continues to use employees for most of the services offered. Larger companies have developed technology to help optimize the services provided.

FAQs.question: Have environmental regulations affected your business?
FAQs.answer: Cleaners are subject to various federal, state and local laws regulating the discharge of harmful chemicals and materials into the environment.

FAQs.question: Do regulations pertinent to your business vary from state to state?
FAQs.answer: Some state regulations require workers to obtain a certification in order to perform certain cleaning services. This ensures that workers have the proper training and understand the applicable laws.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Building exterior cleaning companies rely heavily on labor to perform services on-site, such as servicing pools, driving snow plows and sweeping parking lots. Operators also rely on machines and equipment to fulfill cleaning services.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Much of the industry's sales are derived from the commercial market, where businesses often can pay for services on time.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key distributors and end-users? Are you located close to your target markets and suppliers?
FAQs.answer: It's important for contractors to establish close working relationships with major residential and commercial buildings or building-services management organizations to generate repeat business.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain skilled employees? How do you reward staff that perform well? Are work contracts flexible?
FAQs.answer: Operators must have access to a pool of suitable laborers that have proper experience and work ethic.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? How do you achieve and maintain high service quality?
FAQs.answer: Adopting new cleaning equipment and products can increase productivity and cleaning results.

FAQs.question: How does your company transport its services? Do you follow trends in crude oil and gasoline prices? How do you compensate for high fuel expenses?
FAQs.answer: As the price of oil increases, so do service prices and revenue, albeit at the expense of profit margin.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the number of businesses in the US? Do you use any advertising or promotions to attract businesses?
FAQs.answer: More US businesses expand the industry's potential target market, leading to higher demand for building exterior cleaning services.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? Are you prepared to increase production levels?
FAQs.answer: Within the residential sector, households earning more than $100,000 are the industry's leading market for exterior cleaning services.
